River levels are now falling at the Fosseway, Brokenborough and Great Somerford gauges. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 29 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message: High river levels today and overnight may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible on 28 and 29 January 2026. This information is correct as of 03:15pm on Wednesday 28 January 2026. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 17cm of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 2cm of water on the road. There are currently no issues on Earith causeway. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Norfolk Highways who will decide whether to close the road. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. We are not expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The river level at Huish Episcopi is currently 8.91m. The drain level at Huish Episcopi is 8.6m and rising slowly. Flooding will affect the Langport to Muchelney road if this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the Muchelney to Long Load road above 7.86m, the Muchelney to Thorney road above 7.93m and the Muchelney to Draycott road above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. Pumping will start at Huish Episcopi and Westover stations once river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel will be opened once river spillways stop running. Showers are expected Wednesday, with blustery showers forecast on Thursday and Friday which may be heavy at times. Unsettled conditions continue.
We are monitoring the situation closely. Staff are checking the condition of flood banks and spillways. Avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1PM on 29/01/2026, or as the situation changes.

High river levels on Tuesday have led to flooding. Flooding will affect land, fields, and roads at Cadnam, West Wellow, Landford and Ower throughout today (28/01/2026). Water levels will also be very high around, and affect the mill building at East Wellow. River levels and flood risk will reduce over the next 24hours. items.message: Rivers remain high and flooding is possible on Wednesday 28th January. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Brue and River Sheppey, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around the B3151 Glastonbury to Meare Road. Overtopping is forecast from the Glastonbury Millstream and the River Brue at North Drain and Westhay. The River Brue is forecast to be bankfull upstream of Bruton Dam with field flooding likely. After significant rain on Monday and Tuesday, we are expecting less rain for the remainder of Wednesday however blustery showers are forecast which may be heavy at times. We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 1:00PM on 29 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ock from Watchfield to Abingdon, and also the Letcombe Brook at Wantage, Grove and East Hanney
items.message:
Rising river levels may lead to flooding. 

River levels are responding to recent rainfall and rising along the River Ock and Letcombe Brook. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 28 January 2026, especially near Charney Bassett and Wantage. The forecast is for a predominantly dry day and night with the possibility of light showers. River levels are expected to slowly rise through today as water moves downstream. Levels will be sensitive to further rainfall and are expected to remain high over the coming days. 

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Avoid low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Go to River levels online for updates on current river levels. 

This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 29 Jan 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels remain high this evening as a result of yesterday’s heavy rainfall. Flooding is possible throughout the rest of today, 28 January and into tomorrow, 29 January. Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near rivers, particularly around the Rivers Eden, Eden Brook and Kent Ditch from Blindley Heath to Penshurst including Edenbridge, Hever and Lingfield, with levels at Penshurst still particularly high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00am on 29 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

The Cuckmere River is high in Alfriston, but now falling, following Tuesday's rain. Flood impacts will continue to affect North Street, River Lane, The Old Clergy House, Deans Place Hotel and Litlington Road, Alfriston. Flooding will also continue to affect properties on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. On Mill Lane Hellingly river levels have already fallen significantly, but residual flood impacts will continue to affect fields, roads, and gardens. Only isolated showers are forecast until Friday. River levels will continue to fall and should return nearer to normal by Thursday in Hellingly, but will not fall nearer to normal in Alfriston until Friday. A small amount of rain is forecast Friday and Saturday. More minor flooding could be possible. Don't put yourself or others at risk. Avoid roads that flood (Mill Lane and Church Road Hellingly, and North Street Alfriston). This message will be updated by 14:00 29/01/2026.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

The Western Rother is high but now falling at Lodsbridge near Selham and in Fittleworth. Flood impacts will continue to affect Fittleworth Mill and nearby properties, also isolated mill properties at Lodsbridge near Selham, and roads and fields. Only minor flood impacts are expected between Iping and Midhurst, where river levels have already fallen significantly. In Liss and Sheet river levels have already returned near to normal. Only isolated showers are forecast until Friday. River levels will continue to fall in all communities. River levels should mostly return nearer to normal by Thursday evening, but will stay higher than normal in Fittleworth until next week. A small amount of rain is forecast Friday and Saturday. More minor flooding could be possible. Keep in place any flood protection products you may have. Including in Lodsbridge and Fittleworth. Avoid roads that flood (Iping). This message will be updated by 14:00 29/01/2026.

High tides over the next two days may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 28 and 29 January 2026. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of high tide times. 
Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon. The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it, is for high water level of 1.21 mAODN at 5:30pm this evening with southerly force 3 winds. Second high water is forecast at 1.42 mAODN at 8:30am and south easterly force 5 winds. The third high water is forecast at 1.36 mAODN at 9:45 pm with south easterly force 6 wind. (mAODN is height above average sea level). The river level at the Throop station has also triggered this Alert, and the risk is higher during the next 3 high tides. 
We are closing flood gates and closely monitoring the situation. 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for road closures. 
This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 29 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor Pumping Station is 7.87m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway if this level exceeds 7.45m. The Drain level at Currymoor Pumping Station is currently 7.86m. Cutts Road and New Road are both closed. Water is flowing out of Currymoor over Athelney Spillway and the A361 is also closed. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if the Drain level reaches 8.30m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor, and temporary pumps are also being deployed to Northmoor. After significant rain overnight, we are expecting less rain for the remainder of Tuesday and into Wednesday however blustery showers are forecast which may be heavy at times. We are monitoring the situation closely and staff are checking flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message: Groundwater levels continue to be high and rising, and may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible in the West Dorset area. Groundwater levels are rising in response to the recent rainfall. Levels may continue to rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Further rainfall is expected over the next few days which may see levels continue to rise. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We are closely monitoring the situation . Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 2 February2026 or as the situation changes.

River levels have fallen since the heavy rain from Monday night into Tuesday. Today, Wednesday 28 January 2026, the weather has brought much less rain and this drier weather is forecast to carry on for much of tomorrow, Thursday, interspersed with showers. There is a further band of heavy rain forecast tomorrow evening, which will cause the rivers to rise again, though they are not forecast to get as high as they did on Tuesday. We are very aware that severe flooding occurred in the area of Station Road and the park homes and many properties were badly affected. Therefore we are keeping this Warning in force to reflect the conditions that people have experienced and keep you updated. We will keep reviewing this Warning in the coming days as necessary to reflect the weather conditions and any forecast rise in the rivers. We are closely monitoring the situation, and our staff continue to check rivers for blockages. Please stay safe and vigilant, and look out for updates to this Warning. This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 29 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor Pumping Station is 7.84m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway if this level exceeds 7.45m. The Drain level at Currymoor Pumping Station is currently 7.85m. Cutts Road and New Road remain closed. Water is flowing out of Currymoor over Athelney Spillway and the A361 remains closed. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if the Drain level reaches 8.30m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor stations and additional mobile pumps are now running at Northmoor.

Near Broadbridge Heath, river levels have fallen from their peak, minor flood impacts will continue to affect gardens of mill properties. In Horsham, river levels have fallen significantly, only minor flood impacts affecting fields are expected to remain in Horsham. Only isolated showers are forecast until Friday. items.description: Mansbridge and Woodmill on the River Itchen
items.message:
High river levels are expected to cause flooding on Wednesday. 
Flooding is expected on 28 January 2026 , as a lot of rain (40mm) fell on Monday.   
High tide is forecast at 18:45 and 20:15 28/01/2026 at Southampton. For 1.5 hours either side of high tide, flooding may affect the access road and car parking areas near the White Swan Pub and car garage at Mansbridge. Some water may be forced up through the floor of the Pub. Parts of Riverside Park will also be flooded. Levels may be very high at Gaters Mill. Only isolated showers are forecast today 28/01/2026 and Thursday 29/01/2026. However, the next high tide at 07:30 29/01/2026 is forecast to be 28cm higher. Further flooding impacts are possible during this period. 
We are checking rivers for blockages and liaising with Southampton City Council on operation of Woodmill. 
Activate any flood protection products you may have . Including defences around the White Swan pub. 
This message will be updated by 12:59PM on 29 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

River levels have fallen since the heavy rain from Monday night into Tuesday. Today, Wednesday 28 January 2026, the weather has brought much less rain and this drier weather is forecast to carry on for much of tomorrow, Thursday, interspersed with showers. There is a further band of heavy rain forecast tomorrow evening, which will cause the rivers to rise again, though they are not forecast to get as high as they did on Tuesday. We are very aware that significant flooding occurred in various communities through the Cam valley, and properties were badly affected. Therefore we are keeping this Warning in force to reflect the conditions that people have experienced and keep you updated. We will keep reviewing this Warning in the coming days as necessary to reflect the weather conditions and any forecast rise in the rivers. We are closely monitoring the situation, and our staff continue to check rivers for blockages. Please stay safe and vigilant, and look out for updates to this Warning. This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 29 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently high at our Draycot borehole in the Upper Og Valley. We expect levels to rise over the coming days and levels remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

The forecast is for heavy rain on Tuesday 27 January clearing into a predominantly dry Wednesday 28 January. Showers are then expected into the end of the week. Depending on the rainfall received, we may see localised impacts groundwater impacts. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are closely monitoring rainfall and groundwater levels.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Take particular care when driving through flood water both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. 

This message will be updated by 12:00 28 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is currently 7.84m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.85m. Cutts Road and New Road remain closed. Athelney spillway is running and the A361 remains closed. For road closure information please refer to www.somerset.gov.uk/roads-travel-and-parking/emergency-road-closure-gates/. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor stations and additional mobile pumps are now running at Northmoor. The River Tone level is still too high for pumping at Currymoor. We will commence pumping at Currymoor once river levels allow. 
The weather has improved today, Wednesday 28 January 2026, but remains unsettled and showers are possible this evening and tomorrow (Thursday). Further rain, possibly heavy, is forecast for tomorrow evening.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Meon Valley from East Meon to Soberton
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from Wednesday, 28/01/2026, following a wet January 2026. 
Flooding could affect the electricity sub station in Rectory Lane, Meonstoke. The Winterbourne will begin to flow across Rectory Lane and behind the Buck's Head Pub. Tomorrow (27/01/2026), Storm Chandra will pass through the south of England, bringing up to 50mm of rain to Hampshire. A combination of high river flows and groundwater may affect a couple of cellars of properties on West Meon High Street and Lynch Lane. Lighter rain is forecast from Wednesday (28/01/2026) to Friday (30/01/2026). Groundwater levels at the borehole at Pound Lane, Meonstoke will continue rising through this week. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 30 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

Tomorrow (27/01/2026), Storm Chandra will pass through the south of England, bringing up to 50mm of rain to Hampshire. Lighter rain is forecast from Wednesday (28/01/2026) to Friday (30/01/2026). We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with Hambledon Flood Action Group.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors, low lying properties around Muchelney
items.message: The River Yeo level remains high and the drain level at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station is 8.63m and gradually rising. Flooding affects the Langport to Muchelney road when this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the Muchelney to Long Load road above 7.86m, the Muchelney to Thorney road above 7.93m and the Muchelney to Drayton road above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. Pumping will start at Huish Episcopi and Westover stations once river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel will be opened once spillways stop running. The weather has improved today, Wednesday 28 January 2026, but remains unsettled and showers are possible this evening and tomorrow (Thursday). Further rain, possibly heavy, is forecast for tomorrow evening. We are monitoring the situation closely. Staff are checking the condition of flood banks and spillways. Avoid driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1 PM on 29/01/2026, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Salt Moor and North Moor including Moorland
items.message:
High and continued rising water levels are expected to cause flooding tonight, Wednesday 28/01/2026, and into tomorrow. 
Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads around Moorland including Horlake, Saltmoor, Fordgate and Chadmead. The level in Currymoor has stopped rising and is currently stable, though still very high. Athelney spillway is still running into Saltmoor and Northmoor. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor stations and additional high volume mobile pumps are now running at Northmoor, which will help to gradually slow the rate of rise of floodwater.  
The weather has improved today, Wednesday 28 January 2026, but remains unsettled and showers are possible this evening and tomorrow (Thursday). Further heavy rain is forecast tomorrow evening. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 1 PM on 29 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 30/01/2026, after above average rainfall in January. 
Minor flood impacts could affect fields, the recreation ground, and a small number of cellars in Denton. A small amount of water may appear on Denton Road. Groundwater at Houndean Bottom borehole is expected to stop rising around the 31/01/2026. However, small amounts of rain are forecast Friday and Saturday, with the suggestion of more rain next week. Further groundwater rise could be possible next week, which may cause water to flow towards Vicarage Close and affect areas near the three ponds in South Heighton. If rain continues, flood impacts may remain until mid February. 
We are closely monitoring the situation , including rainfall, groundwater and forecasts. 
Don't put yourself or others at risk . Avoid roads that flood (Denton Road). Ensure pumps work. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 02 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in upper River Ems Valley
items.message:

Springs will appear, water will be in fields, and small amounts of water could flood down roads. Groundwater at Compton borehole is expected to pause rising around the 01/02/2026. However, small amounts of rain are forecast Friday and Saturday. More rain is suggested next week. If further rain occurs further groundwater rise could cause more water to flow along Stoughton main road, the road from East Marden, between Cooks Lane and Barley Mow in Walderton, the B2146 near Woodlands Lane. Towards the end of the first week of February water could also affect cellars in Stoughton and Walderton. 
We are closely monitoring the situation , including rainfall, groundwater and forecasts. 
Don't put yourself or others at risk . Avoid roads that flood (Stoughton, Walderton). Ensure pumps work.
